text: in october two thousand eight the New
York Times began following several small
business owners throughout the city to
track their effort to survive the
economic downturn amid increasingly
positive financial news we asked them if
they believe the recession is over if
the recession is over I mean then you
won't you won't be able to see places
closing down we sell the Boeing we sell
to GM we sell afford without a Chrysler
and I think you'd be hard-pressed for
those companies to tell you that the
recession is over i would say for us as
a business I mean a few more months
hopefully and we'll be back to live was
supposed to be six months ago Mike menna
of manas quality meats in the Bronx was
hopeful about his butcher shops
prospects for this summer it seems like
it's thought to come back maybe the nice
weather was maybe one thing with a
sizeable energy bill hanging over his
head the stakes were high he bought
acute sauce but the summer was unusually
cold dampening prospects for a good
barbecue season yeah we lost all of june
half of july with the weather but we
saved on coned so with that helped me i
didn't put the air on 24 gazebo it's not
back where it's supposed to be but it's
definitely better start seeing a light
at the end of the tunnel right after
Labor Day you get a nice shot in the arm
and hopefully be have a nice consistent
fall right into the holiday so busy
holiday season this was a family
business my dad and my uncle's like 40
years ago started and things was so much
different than life was so much easier
the overhead was hardly anything and
everybody shopped at the local butcher
it's not like that anymore
located mere blocks from Wall Street
Mohammed Shami is restaurant alpha news
was hit hard by the financial collapse
but received an unexpected helping hand
my Lando dropped my rent trying to help
me if the economy it start to recover
then I'll go back to the my old room we
spoke to mr. Shah me in August his
landlord had not yet raised the rent
comparing the last six months I see a
little bit of improvement as far as
lunch but like I said dinner it's still
the same thing some months it's even
worse I I don't know if because I cut
down on some expenses and I'm working
more maybe that I let my health
insurance go I don't know if it's all
these combination it made a difference
plus I mean I think like I said I
noticed there is a little bit of
improvement especially in the past month
month and a half at lunchtime she's come
up later tahini and hot salsa yeah I was
pulling the work for more than two
people and three people might refer now
I start to feel it you know I'm not a
kid anymore i mean i'm almost 55 years
old and for the past six years now i
haven't taken a vacation so I'm hoping
next year after my son graduate he told
me that you need to take a break and he
is gonna be filling in for me every
summer I'll at work I learned something
new I have like a step up in some sort
of responsibility I know he's giving you
a little bit more trust I see more and I
learned
no we're growing together six months ago
Wayne sosin president of workmen cycles
of ozone park queens was looking for a
way to deal with a shrinking customer
base the key for us is to find new
customers new uses for the products we
currently make and tweaking them a
little bit so that they could reach some
new markets like special needs etc when
he spoke to mr. sosin in August he
sounded a note of optimism so we really
had to come up with an alternate
strategy of finding other customers for
our existing products and we've actually
come across some really exciting
opportunities using works Minh cycles
for bike share programs which is a
growing market we've successfully
completed some programs now we're
certain universities are using our
bicycles for their students to ride
around campus so I think ultimately I've
always said this from the beginning of
this recession is that I know we make
the right product but the question is
when will people open up the pocketbooks
ultimately will be in great shape but
short term you know it's it's not the
case this place it meant so much it
means so much to me I build it up from
scratch I build it with my own hand did
I do anything differently I don't think
so so I enjoy what I do I like being in
this neighborhood I like my customers
and I like to continue pushing forward
do whatever it takes to stay
